CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The PCE of P4 : PC71BM also showed a higher PCE value than P1 and P7 , with a J SC of 12.95 mA / cm^2. In contrast , the PCE suddenly decreased in the blended device of P5 and PC61BM ( 3.02% ) and further decreased in P6 ( 2.09% ) , mainly due to the significant decrease of the J SC . The low J SC values of P5 and P6 were unexpected , considering the lower band gaps of P5 ( 1.49 eV ) and P6 ( 1.55 eV ) compared to that of P7 ( 1.85 eV ). To better understand the nonlinear compositional dependence of the J SC values , the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) of hole - only devices of the P1 , P3 , P4 , P5 , and P7 blended devices were measured and compared ( Figure S5 ). The hole - only devices were constructed under optimized device conditions with the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / blends / Au. The hole mobilities of P1 , P3 , P4 , P5 , and P7 were 1.14 × 10^-4 , 1.13 × 10^-4 , 1.09 × 10^-4 , 1.10 × 10^-4 , and 1.18 × 10^-5 cm^2 / ( V s ) , respectively , showing that the hole mobilities of all random terpolymers were similar to or 1 order of magnitude higher than their parent polymers. Therefore , the trend of the J SC can not be explained solely by the changes in the optical properties and the hole mobilities. To gain a better understanding of the nonlinear compositional dependence of the J SC and PCE values of the PBDTT- DPP - TPD random terpolymers , the molecular geometries and the electron density distribution were simulated using density functional theory ( DFT ) at the B3LYP / 6-31G(d,p) level with the Spartan 08 software package. Three repeating units were taken as a model for calculations , and methyl was used instead of the long side chains to reduce the computational time. Four model compounds , ( BDTT - DPP ) 3 , (BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP) , (BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD) , and ( BDTT - TPD ) 3 were used and calculated for comparison. The optimized molecular geometries of the models and their calculated HOMO and LUMO frontier orbitals are depicted in Figure 5 and Figure S7. In general , for alternative copolymers , the electron density in the HOMO wave functions is well delocalized. However , the LUMO wave function shows a different degree of localization in the electron density dependent on the types of the electron - withdrawing units. 46,47 This tendency was observed in ( BDTT - DPP ) 3 and ( BDTT - TPD ) 3 .

Let's think step by step.

1. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency
2. P4 : PC71BM: Polymer blend
3. P1: A type of material (polymer or organic compound)
4. P7: A type of material (polymer or organic compound)
5. Blended device of P5 and PC61BM: Polymer blend
6. P6: A type of material (polymer or organic compound)
7. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide
8. PEDOT:PSS: Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulfonate
9. Au: Gold
10. P1, P3, P4, P5, P7: Different types of materials (polymers or organic compounds)
11. BDTT-DPP: A type of electron-donating unit in a polymer or organic compound
12. BDTT-TPD: A type of electron-donating unit in a polymer or organic compound
13. (BDTT-DPP)3: A model compound with three repeating units of BDTT-DPP
14. (BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP): A model compound with a repeating unit arrangement of BDTT-DPP, BDTT-TPD, and BDTT-DPP
15. (BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD): A model compound with a repeating unit arrangement of BDTT-TPD, BDTT-DPP, and BDTT-TPD
16. (BDTT-TPD)3: A model compound with three repeating units of BDTT-TPD

Paragraph: The PCE of P4 : PC71BM also showed a higher PCE value than P1 and P7 , with a J SC of 12.95 mA / cm^2. In contrast , the PCE suddenly decreased in the blended device of P5 and PC61BM ( 3.02% ) and further decreased in P6 ( 2.09% ) , mainly due to the significant decrease of the J SC . The low J SC values of P5 and P6 were unexpected , considering the lower band gaps of P5 ( 1.49 eV ) and P6 ( 1.55 eV ) compared to that of P7 ( 1.85 eV ). To better understand the nonlinear compositional dependence of the J SC values , the space - chargelimited current ( SCLC ) of hole - only devices of the P1 , P3 , P4 , P5 , and P7 blended devices were measured and compared ( Figure S5 ). The hole - only devices were constructed under optimized device conditions with the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / blends / Au. The hole mobilities of P1 , P3 , P4 , P5 , and P7 were 1.14 × 10^-4 , 1.13 × 10^-4 , 1.09 × 10^-4 , 1.10 × 10^-4 , and 1.18 × 10^-5 cm^2 / ( V s ) , respectively , showing that the hole mobilities of all random terpolymers were similar to or 1 order of magnitude higher than their parent polymers. Three repeating units were taken as a model for calculations , and methyl was used instead of the long side chains to reduce the computational time. Four model compounds , ( BDTT - DPP ) 3 , (BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP) , (BDTT-TPD)-(BDTT-DPP)-(BDTT-TPD) , and ( BDTT - TPD ) 3 were used and calculated for comparison. The optimized molecular geometries of the models and their calculated HOMO and LUMO frontier orbitals are depicted in Figure 5 and Figure S7. In general , for alternative copolymers , the electron density in the HOMO wave functions is well delocalized. However , the LUMO wave function shows a different degree of localization in the electron density dependent on the types of the electron - withdrawing units. 46,47 This tendency was observed in ( BDTT - DPP ) 3 and ( BDTT - TPD ) 3 .

Let's think step by step.

1. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE of P4 : PC71BM, PCE of blended device of P5 and PC61BM, PCE of P6)
2. J SC: Short-circuit current density (J SC of P4 : PC71BM, J SC of blended device of P5 and PC61BM, J SC of P6)
3. P1, P3, P4, P5, P6, P7: These are materials, but their exact names or identities are not provided in the paragraph.
4. PC61BM: A material, possibly a fullerene derivative.
5. PC71BM: A material, possibly a fullerene derivative.
6. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide, a common material used as a transparent electrode in organic solar cells.
7. PEDOT:PSS: Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulfonate, a common material used as a hole transport layer in organic solar cells.
8. Au: Gold, a material used as a top electrode in organic solar cells.
9. Hole-only devices: A device structure used to measure the hole mobility of organic semiconductors.
10. BDTT-DPP: A repeating unit in one of the polymers, possibly a donor material.
11. BDTT-TPD: A repeating unit in one of the polymers, possibly a donor material.
12. HOMO: Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital, a measure of the electron-donating ability of a material.
13. LUMO: Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital, a measure of the electron-accepting ability of a material.
14. DFT: Density Functional Theory, a computational method used to simulate the molecular geometries and electron density distribution of materials.
15. B3LYP/6-31G(d,p): A level of theory used in DFT calculations.
16. Spartan 08: A software package used for DFT calculations.
